Factors and levels were: stirring speed (zero or 840 rpm), temperature (28 or 50 °C), dye concentration (100 or 300 mg/L) and current density (20 or 50 A/m2). It was used a concentration NaCl as support electrolyte, and contrary to other studies all the runs were carried out at the same electric charge (5,000 C/L). Removals around 99% colour and 84% in DOC were obtained. Both materials were competitive for colour and DOC removal..

Authors: dos Reis G.B.; Rodriguez R.D.F.; dos Santos C.I.L.; Gontijo L.A.P.; Schiavon M.A.; De Boni L.; Mendonca C.R.; Vivas M.G.
Author full names: dos Reis, George B. (57204417482); Rodriguez, Ruben D.F. (56681659100); dos Santos, Calink I.L. (58253125100); Gontijo, Leiriana A.P. (57201009724); Schiavon, Marco A. (7006953223); De Boni, Leonardo (6603197191); Mendonca, Cleber R. (7005345259); Vivas, Marcelo G. (36082008000)
Title: Femtosecond two-photon absorption spectroscopy of copper indium sulfide quantum dots: A structure-optical properties relationship
Affiliations: Laboratório de Espectroscopia Óptica e Fotônica, Universidade Federal de Alfenas, Poços de Caldas, MG, Brazil; Instituto de Física de São Carlos, Universidade de São Paulo, São Carlos, 13560-970, SP, Brazil; Universidad de la Costa, departamento de ciencias naturales y exactas, 58 #55-66, Barranquilla, 080002, Colombia; Departamento de Ciências naturais, Universidade Federal de São Joao del-Rei, MG, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: dos Reis G.B., Laboratório de Espectroscopia Óptica e Fotônica, Universidade Federal de Alfenas, Poços de Caldas, MG, Brazil; Rodriguez R.D.F., Instituto de Física de São Carlos, Universidade de São Paulo, São Carlos, 13560-970, SP, Brazil, Universidad de la Costa, departamento de ciencias naturales y exactas, 58 #55-66, Barranquilla, 080002, Colombia; dos Santos C.I.L., Departamento de Ciências naturais, Universidade Federal de São Joao del-Rei, MG, Brazil; Gontijo L.A.P., Departamento de Ciências naturais, Universidade Federal de São Joao del-Rei, MG, Brazil; Schiavon M.A., Departamento de Ciências naturais, Universidade Federal de São Joao del-Rei, MG, Brazil; De Boni L., Instituto de Física de São Carlos, Universidade de São Paulo, São Carlos, 13560-970, SP, Brazil; Mendonca C.R., Instituto de Física de São Carlos, Universidade de São Paulo, São Carlos, 13560-970, SP, Brazil; Vivas M.G., Laboratório de Espectroscopia Óptica e Fotônica, Universidade Federal de Alfenas, Poços de Caldas, MG, Brazil
Abstract: We have interpreted the two-photon absorption spectrum of water-soluble copper indium sulfide (CIS) QDs with stoichiometry 0.18 (Cu), 0.42 (In), and 2 (S) and an average diameter of approximately 2.6 nm. For that, we employed the wavelength-tunable femtosecond Z-scan technique and the parabolic effective-mass approximation model, in which the excitonic transition energies were phenomenologically corrected due to the stoichiometry of the nanocrystal. This model considers a conduction band and three valence sub-bands allowing excitonic transitions via centrosymmetric (?l = ±1, where l is the angular momentum of the absorbing state) and non-centrosymmetric (?l = 0) channels. In such case, this became relevant because the CIS QDs with chalcopyrite crystalline structure is a non-centrosymmetric semiconductor. Thus, our experimental results pointed out two 2 PA allowed bands located at 715 nm (2hv = 3.47 eV) and 625 nm (2hv = 3.97 eV) with cross sections of (6.3 ± 1.0) x 102 GM and (4.5 ± 0.7) x 102 GM, respectively. According to the theoretical model, these 2 PA bands can be ascribed to the 1P1/2(h3) ? 1S3/2(e) (lower energy band) and 1P1/2(hheavy) ? 1S3/2(e) (90%)/(10%)1P1/2(hsplit-off) ? 1P3/2(e) (higher energy band) excitonic transitions. A good agreement (magnitude and spectral position) between the experimental and theoretical data were obtained. However, our experimental data suggest that the higher-energy 2 PA band may have other contributions due to the mixing between the heavy- and the light-hole bands, which the effective mass model does not take into consideration.
Author Keywords: CuInS<sub>2</sub> quantum dots; Femtosecond laser; Nanomaterials; Parabolic effective-mass approximation model; Two-photon absorption; Wavelength-tunable femtosecond Z-scan technique
Index Keywords: Absorption spectroscopy; Band structure; Femtosecond lasers; Indium sulfide; Nanocrystals; Nanostructured materials; Optical properties; Photons; Quantum dot lasers; Semiconductor quantum dots; Stoichiometry; Sulfur compounds; Two photon processes; Water absorption; Copper indium sulfides; Crystalline structure; Effective mass approximation; Femtoseconds; Two photon absorption; Two-photon absorption spectroscopy; Two-photon absorption spectrum; Water-soluble copper; Copper compounds

Authors: Vengoechea A.M.; Rojano R.E.; Arregoces H.A.
Author full names: Vengoechea, Alejandra M. (57205763832); Rojano, Roberto E. (35608191100); Arregoces, Heli A. (56426426500)
Title: Dispersion and concentration of PM10 particles in a Caribbean coastal city; [Dispersión y concentración de aerosoles marinos PM10 en una ciudad costera del caribe]
Affiliations: Grupo de Investigación GISA, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de La Guajira, Km 5, Vía a Maicao, Colombia
Authors with affiliations: Vengoechea A.M., Grupo de Investigación GISA, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de La Guajira, Km 5, Vía a Maicao, Colombia; Rojano R.E., Grupo de Investigación GISA, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de La Guajira, Km 5, Vía a Maicao, Colombia; Arregoces H.A., Grupo de Investigación GISA, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de La Guajira, Km 5, Vía a Maicao, Colombia
Abstract: In this study, the concentrations of marine aerosols estimated with the model CALPUFF (a multi-layer, multi-species, non-steady-state puff dispersion) were compared with the concentrations of PM10 monitored near the coast with minimum volume gravimetric equipment. It was found that the contribution of marine aerosols to the mass of PM10 can be significant, reaching between 20% and 27%. Concentrations between 5 and 15 g/m                             3                              were estimated on streets that are less than 100 meters from the beach. The maximum concentrations were found at the sampling point located offshore. The correlation was strong and positive at this same point (r                             2                              = 0.65). In the dispersion analysis, the impact of marine aerosols was observed more than 20 km from the beach in the direction of the wind, with levels between 1.65 g/m                             3                              y 15.02 g/m                             3                             . In the monitoring with the gravimetric equipment, a maximum concentration of PM10 of 77.98 g/m                             3                              and a minimum concentration of 2.82 g/m                             3                              was obtained. The results show that CALPUFF provides reasonable predictions of long-term marine pollutant deposition patterns.
Author Keywords: CALPUFF; Dispersion; Marine aerosols; Modeling; PM10
Index Keywords: Atmospheric movements; Beaches; Dispersion (waves); Marine pollution; Models; Odor control; Offshore oil well production; Calpuff; Deposition patterns; Dispersion analysis; Marine aerosols; Marine pollutants; Maximum concentrations; PM10; Puff dispersions; Aerosols
